newsitem.title: UK: North Sea, West African crude firm, Med depressed.
newsitem.headline: North Sea, West African crude firm, Med depressed.

text.p: North Sea and West African crude markets were firm on Thursday, but the Mediterranean sour market was seen under pressure from the onset of Iraqi exports.
Several North Sea grades traded at steady to firmer numbers with two Forties cargoes, loading Jan 4-6 and Jan 6-8, fetching Dated Brent +28 cents.

After four cargoes were sold on Tuesday, traders said that the first decade Forties programme was virtually sold out and some expected differentials for second decade cargoes to command a premium of more than 30 cents to Dated Brent.
A Statfjord cargo for Jan 8-10 sold at Dtd Brent +28 cts.
That was 10 cents above the price of a December-loading cargo traded late last week. A Jan 10-12 Statfjord traded at Dated +26 cents.
Other Norwegian grades also fetched stronger prices, with a Dec 7-9 Troll sold at Dated Brent +40 cents and a Dec 7-9 Gullfaks C traded at Dated +37.5 cents.

A Dec 27-29 Brent was sold early to a Wall Street trader for Jan Brent -18.5 cents, but late Dec and early Jan barrels were assessed at or above Jan -12/13 cents later in line with next week's cfds which made further gains to talk around Feb Brent +40 cents.
The sole Brent cargo nominated from the paper chains was kept by Shell UK, traders said.
Feb Brent paper fell back sharply after trading at $23.73 and $23.66 a barrel to talk some 35-40 cents down at $23.30/$23.35 in line with IPE screen levels at 1840 GMT.
The forward paper curve also shed earlier gains. Jan/Feb talked either side of +50/54 cents after trading at +55 cents and Feb/March was discussed at +58/62 in late trade.
West African grades were firm, with arbitrage opportunities to both the U.S. and Asia, traders said.
